definition:
The *alternating factorial* $af(n)$ of a positive integer $n$ is the sum
$$af(n) = \sum_{i = 1}^n (-1)^{n - i}i!,$$ which can also be expressed
with the recurrence relation $af(n) = n! - af(n - 1)$ with starting
condition $af(1) = 1$. The notation nÂ¡! (alternating an inverted
exclamation mark with a regular exclamation mark) has been proposed by
analogy to that of the double factorial, but has not gained much
support, in part because of TeX’s lack of support for Spanish
characters.

The first few alternating factorials, listed in A005165 of Sloane’s
OEIS, are 1, 5, 19, 101, 619, 4421.

In 1999, Miodrag Zivković proved that $\gcd(n, af(n)) = 1$ and that the
set of alternating factorials that are prime numbers is finite.
$af(661)$ is the largest such known prime.
